head.title: The Web Isn't Always Up to the Minute

hedline.hl1: The Web Isn't Always Up to the Minute

abstract.p: Study of 3,634 Web journals, known as blogs, finds that two-thirds had not been updated for at least two months and that a quarter had not been updated since their creation (S)

block.p: The Internet provides loads of information for consumers and businesses, quickly and often, but it is also littered with Web sites that are woefully out of date.
For example, a recent study of 3,634 Web journals, known as blogs, found that two-thirds had not been updated for at least two months, and that a quarter had not been updated since their creation.
The Internet provides loads of information for consumers and businesses, quickly and often, but it is also littered with Web sites that are woefully out of date.
For example, a recent study of 3,634 Web journals, known as blogs, found that two-thirds had not been updated for at least two months, and that a quarter had not been updated since their creation.

Jeffrey Henning, chief technology officer at the Perseus Development Corporation, a research firm that conducted the study and released its results last month, says that many people simply grow tired of maintaining their sites.
Others abandon them because an anticipated event that prompted their creation has come and gone.

Clifford R. Kurtzman of Houston kept his Year2000.com site up and running, without updates, for two years after the turn of the century. He acknowledged that ''there was so much on it that was out of date, and links that didn't work.''
Today, he uses the site to promote a newsletter on business and innovation. ''Having extra junk out there just makes the process of searching for good stuff even harder,'' he said.
It also costs money. Unless they use a free service like GeoCities, developers of Web sites must pay fees for Web hosting and domain names.
